Award.AwardTitle: Nanogap Electrochemistry of Interfacial Charge-Transfer Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Shigeru Amemiya at University of Pittsburgh and his group will be utilizing a nanogap (a gap with a width of <10 nm) to develop the novel electrochemical method that combines cyclic voltammetry (CV) with scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM). The nanogap-based approach that was developed in the Amemiya laboratory overcomes the limitations of widely used CV and SECM methods and enables completely new measurements of interfacial charge-transfer reactions at extremely high rates on laterally heterogeneous surfaces. The versatile nanoelectrochemical method will be useful for the characterization of nanomaterials such as monolayer graphene and electrocatalytic nanoparticles, as well as for investigation of rapid charge-transfer reactions such as electron transfer at redox-active self-assembled monolayers and ion transfer at liquid/liquid interfaces. Such studies will massively augment our knowledge and understanding of interfacial charge-transfer reactions, which are the basis of future technological developments in energy conversion and storage, molecular electronics, and ion sensing and separation in addition to fundamental advancements in various scientific areas, especially, in electrochemistry, nanosceince, and material science.

The implementation of the nanogap-based electrochemical method as a routine experimental tool among scientific community will be accelerated by commercializing tailor-made nanoelectrodes and by sharing simulation programs for data analysis. The integration of the electrochemical research into undergraduate teaching will be promoted by the development of pencil-lead-based voltammetric electrodes as an educational tool to discover the lipophilicity of various ions as the critical molecular property related to their environmental toxicity and pharmaceutical activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research and educational activities under this completed project were integrated toward the realization of a truly energy-efficient, clean society. Scientifically, this project was focused on the development of new experimental strategies to study the electrochemical reactivity of various interfaces, especially, interfaces between carbon and water. Importantly, carbon/water interfaces play a crucial role for the development of various energy devices including batteries, solar cells, fuel cells, and supercapacitors. These electrochemical devices can generate and store electricity in sustainable and renewable ways and have been extensively developed by using not only traditional carbon materials, but also emerging carbon nanomaterials such as graphene and carbon nanotubes. It, however, is not fundamentally understood how important electrochemical reactions such as the oxidation and reduction of fuels at carbon/solution interfaces are affected by the properties of carbon surfaces such as their electronic structure, defect, and contamination. A lack of this fundamental knowledge has been significantly limiting the development of the potentially highly efficient and clean energy devices.

Under this completed project, we made two significant accomplishments, which will dramatically improve the performance of carbon-based electrochemical energy devices. Our new measurement technologies revealed that the performance of these importance devices has been significantly compromised by the adventitious contamination of the carbon/water interfaces with organic molecules from ambient air as well as even highly purified water. The sources of these adventitious contaminant molecules were identified by employing highly sensitive electrochemical sensors developed in our laboratory. To solve this problem, we developed new approaches to protect clean carbon surfaces from adventitious organic contaminants by condensing a nanometer-thick adlayer of water on the surfaces in humidified air and also by further removing organic impurities from ultrapure water. Significantly, these simple approaches can be not only readily implementable into many research laboratories in the large and important fields of carbon electrochemistry and carbon material science, but also affordable in industrial settings for the mass production of high-performance energy devices based on carbon materials.

In addition to these research activities, we successfully recruited and trained an undergraduate student, female students, and a student from an underrepresented group through collaborative research activities with international and industrial partners to ensure their successful STEM careers in energy research and development.
